The public. They don't understand the necessity of our actions. They're blind to the threat that we're fighting against. But I'll tell you this - I've seen the enemy up close, and I know what they're capable of. They're not human, not like us. They're a plague, a disease that needs to be eradicated.

To make the public see things my way, I'd use every tool at my disposal. I'd start by painting a picture of the enemy as a monstrous, ruthless force that will stop at nothing to destroy our way of life. I'd use propaganda, yes, but it's not propaganda if it's the truth, is it? I'd show them the atrocities that the enemy has committed, the innocent lives they've destroyed. I'd make them see that we're not just fighting for our own survival, but for the survival of humanity itself.

I'd also use social and cultural influences to my advantage. I'd appeal to people's sense of patriotism, their sense of duty to their country and their fellow citizens. I'd remind them that we're fighting for a higher cause, for a world where our children can grow up safe and free. And I'd make sure that our message is consistent, that every soldier, every officer, every spokesperson is singing the same tune.

But let's be clear - the public doesn't need to know everything. They don't need to know the details of our operations, the methods we use to achieve our goals. They just need to know that we're winning, that we're making progress, and that we're doing whatever it takes to protect them.
